Key Match Events: India won by 6 wickets (with 1 ball remaining).
Pre-Game Insights: Pressure on India as New Zealand look to seal the series in Lucknow.
The focus will be on India's top order with Prithvi Shaw waiting in the wings.
New Zealand finally have a win on this tour after being whitewashed in the ODI series.
Mitchell Santner led from the front with the ball to give New Zealand hope of taking home the T20I series.
Finn Allen gave New Zealand a quick start and their bowlers struck with the new ball.
India's top order caused New Zealand big trouble during the ODIs.
In Ranchi, Shubman Gill, Ishan Kishan, and Rahul Tripathi contributed only 11 runs from 17 balls as India slipped to 15 for 3 in the fourth over.
India do have Prithvi Shaw in the squad, but Shubman Gill was ahead of him in the pecking order.
Rahul Tripathi made his T20I debut during the Sri Lanka series and smashed 35 off just 16 balls in his second game.
Glenn Phillips had landed in India on the back of a match-winning 63 not out off 42 balls against Pakistan in the ODI series decider.
Washington Sundar and Kuldeep Yadav bowled economic spells in Ranchi, while also picking up three wickets between them.
Arshdeep Singh had figures of 1 for 24 from three overs before leaking 27 in the final over.
New Zealand may not want to change a winning combination, meaning left-arm seamer Ben Lister will have to wait for his debut.
All five T20Is hosted by the Ekana Stadium to date have been won by the side batting first.
With New Zealand defending 176 successfully in the first T20I despite a threat of dew in the second innings, both teams may prefer batting first after winning the toss.
Miscellaneous Highlights: West Indies have featured in four out of the five T20Is played at this venue. India in only two.
India's previous T20I in Lucknow was in February 2022. Only Kishan and Deepak Hooda from that XI may play on Sunday.
